sanguinekane

Just because Dolphins start using tools doesn't mean that one will give birth to a chipmunk!
 
 Get real, evolution is a fairytale!! :)

 
 Yes, because we all know that evolution happens in one giant leap. emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 I see this as evidence that particular dolphins may be developing the ability to use tools, and therefore may eventually lead the species to greater intelligence.
Kronus

I see this as evidence that particular dolphins may be developing the ability to use tools, and therefore may eventually lead the species to greater intelligence.

 
 It could also be a branching point, with non-tool using dolphins continuing as they are while the tool users develop into a different species. Just like how man branched off from the other primates.
gnojek
Isn't that the way it usually works?
Kronus

Isn't that the way it usually works?

 
 Not always. Sometimes the "other" group gets completely supplanted and dies out. I don't have the data to say which scenario is more common. I suspect the answer is, "It depends"
Beowulf Lee
Wouldn't the tool using ones have to be isolated first, for them to have a significant impact on the entire gene pool?
trebor

Wouldn't the tool using ones have to be isolated first, for them to have a significant impact on the entire gene pool?

 
 In general, the group would have to be isolated to allow for enough genetic drift to occur that there is no ability to interbreed.
